subject: Communication
title: The Three-Act Structure
description: A 60-second lesson on The Three-Act Structure.

hook.text: Setup, confrontation, resolution. Three acts. It's the backbone of almost every movie, play, and novel.

buildup.text: Act 1 introduces the world and the problem (~25%). Act 2 is the struggle (~50%). Act 3 is the resolution (~25%).

discovery.text: Aristotle described it first: a beginning that hooks, a middle that complicates, an end that resolves.

twist.text: The midpoint twist â€” a surprise in the middle of Act 2 â€” separates good stories from forgettable ones.

climax.text: Pixar, Marvel, and every screenwriting school teaches this structure because audiences intuitively expect it.

punchline.text: Three acts. Two thousand years. Still unbeaten.

quiz.question: What percentage of a three-act story does Act 2 typically occupy?
